sentence: There's an old saying about media interviews: Reporters can ask any question they want, and the speaker can answer it any way they want.
This idea seems to be equally valid for questions about public company earnings.
Companies are required by regulators to report their earnings using Generally Accepted Accounting Principles, or GAAP .

These GAAP earnings, compiled based on a set of standardized rules and audited by independent accountants, foster comparisons across companies and build trust in the integrity of reported financial results.
Managements must formally certify every quarter that their reported financials accurately follow GAAP.
However, companies are free to report earnings using their own accounting rules, too.
These rules usually adjust the GAAP earnings to exclude expenses that management believes are not normal costs of doing business.
Often labeled as "adjusted" or "pro forma," Non-GAAP adjustments are not uniform among similar companies and can sometimes change even within the same company.
Companies have wide latitude in creating their Non-GAAP results, which are not audited and don't require formal certification by management.
Just how large are these adjustments?

According to respected data provider FactSet [1] , for first quarter 2016 earnings, companies in the Dow Jones Industrial Average reported Non-GAAP earnings that were 9.1% higher than their GAAP earnings.
And year-over-year earnings growth was 3.9% using Non-GAAP earnings compared to a near-flat 0.7% using GAAP earnings growth.
These differences can be found across all types of companies and have widened in recent years.
The gap from GAAP matters for two reasons: First, the higher earnings base can mean a higher stock price when a given P/E multiple is applied.

And second, if adjusted numbers provide a smoother and higher growth pattern (as they usually do), it can be tempting to reward the company with a higher P/E multiple, also possibly boosting the share price.
No wonder managements increasingly use Non-GAAP results.
Managements will argue that these Non-GAAP earnings help investors understand the economics of the core business.
There is some logic to this: If litigation, acquisitions or restructurings are rare, removing their costs can clarify underlying profits.
But what used to be a rare adjustment has seemingly become commonplace.
Once a company starts down the "adjusted" earnings path, it rarely ends the practice.
Every quarter brings some new reason to exclude this expense or that unusual item.
The result: recurring non-recurring expenses.
Just as important, legitimate non-recurring items have real costs and may be more recurring than they seem.
What company in today's competitive economy truly is immune from a future restructuring or from litigation, or won't make any more acquisitions?
Such expenses may be infrequent but they may still be normal costs of doing business.
Blue chip company IBM reported 2Q16 Non-GAAP earnings that were 13% higher than its GAAP earnings.
The difference was from acquisition-related and retirement/pension costs.
Yet IBM is always acquiring companies and routinely has costs from employee retirements.

Some companies elevate Non-GAAP adjustments to an art form: Software Salesforce.com ( CRM ), with a $54 billion market cap, has not reported an annual GAAP profit since fiscal 2011, losing a cumulative $824 million in the past five years.
However, by excluding acquisition-related amortization and stock-based compensation expenses, it has earned profits of over $1.5 billion during the same time period.
Investors would be hard-pressed to agree that these expenses are not a regular part of the company's core business.
Perhaps it's not a surprise that some veteran investors have said only half-jokingly that companies might as well just report EBBS (earnings before bad stuff), or EBE (earnings before expenses).
What is a smart investor to do?
Looking to Wall Street analysts may not help much, as they usually follow management's lead or make their own adjustments.
Consensus estimates can include adjustments that are not comparable.
A good place to start is in the company's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission - in which Non-GAAP earnings must be reconciled with GAAP results.
Earnings conference call transcripts, available for free for most companies, can reveal management's reasoning.
Investors will also want to look at history - how often and how large have adjustments been over the past five years?
To be most effective, the investor can use both GAAP and Non-GAAP numbers.
Combined, they can give a decent picture of what the core business earns plus what other costs it must carry, even if somewhat rare.
Minding the GAAP gap can help improve the chances that your stock profits become recurring.
[1] Gulf Between Non-GAAP, GAAP EPS Estimates Grows, May 20, 2016, FactSet.
Differences mentioned in this article are based on median differences.
Average differences were considerably larger, which includes the outsized impact of energy company write-offs.
